name.str_pl: copies of Sundered Sky Ch. I

description: "In the primordial era, mankind was a nothing more than mere monkeys. Fleeing from danger, scared of foul beasts. A putrid existence. Yet it was humanity. Only Human. However, with the fall of an unwanted invader, the paradigm shifted. Content no more, humans walked towards the light, or what they thought was the light. They chased the glory of stars, not realizing the stars were luring them in."

name.str_pl: copies of Sundered Sky Ch. II

description: "Under the warmth of the sun, early man frolicked in the summer breeze and earthen mud. Prodigies appeared one by one to bring knowledge itself to higher esteem. Names were gifted to things of all kinds, including humans themselves. Grunts and groans would not suffice. Talents who etched sounds across surfaces produced the first words of man. It was a tale of two brothers, both had the same power but vastly different ideals."

name.str_pl: copies of Sundered Sky Ch. III

description: "The sun hung atop the firmament for as long as man could remember. But one day, the sun began to fade and shimmer. It waned in its towering palace of gold and gems and hid itself behind the edge of the world. In darkness, people encountered First Fear. The moon arose to help, yet its brightness was weak and feeble. Yet for many, it was enough. A group of builders sought to reinvigorate the spark of sky and they disappeared off West. Men asked where they were going. 'West. How far? As far as necessary. If twenty is not enough, twenty times twenty.'"

name.str_pl: copies of Sundered Sky Ch. IV

description: "Names were sung between the disparate kinds of people. Names, holy and profound, devout and profane. Soon, every thing had a unique name for each people. One said this, the other said that. Divided, we became. In the clouds a King forged a tower of dreams to unify the will. The people tore it down, proclaiming the will belonged only to the one who pilfered divinity. How dare they. The King was distraught, but it was no use. The songs were broken and splintered. Man would never hear the voice again."

name.str_pl: copies of Sundered Sky Ch. V

description: "No matter how many eons pass, even if the ocean were to evaporate under the scorching claws of the Golden One, even if the naked winds of the void were to cut through our flesh and bone, we will always aspire to reach the true skies."
